content: How can I help you today?

I guess I’m here because my wife really pushed me to come. Things have been tough at home—mainly with my son and his behavior issues. It's putting a strain on our marriage, and honestly, I don’t even know where to start. I’m just feeling overwhelmed.

It sounds like things feel heavy right now with everything going on at home. Facing challenges with your son and dealing with strain in your marriage must take a lot of energy. Feeling overwhelmed seems like it can make it tough to figure out where to even begin. What’s been on your mind the most about all of this?

I think it's my son. He's been acting out so much, and I feel like we’ve tried everything, but nothing works. It's frustrating because it's affecting my relationship with my wife, and I feel like I’m failing as a parent. I don’t even know how to reach him anymore.

It sounds like you're putting so much effort into trying to help your son, but when things aren’t improving, it leaves you feeling frustrated and questioning yourself as a parent. That's a really tough spot to be in, especially with the added strain on your relationship with your wife. What has it been like trying to support him through these challenges?

It feels like no matter what we do—whether it’s setting boundaries, talking to him, or trying to be more patient—it doesn’t make a difference. He just gets angrier, or shuts down completely. It’s like I can’t reach him, and it’s exhausting. My wife and I keep arguing about what’s best for him, and I can feel the distance growing between us. It’s like I’m losing him and my family all at once.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot—doing everything you can for your son but feeling like he’s slipping away, while also feeling the weight of growing tension with your wife. It must be exhausting to pour so much energy into trying to help and still face those feelings of distance and struggle. What keeps you going, even with everything weighing on you?

I guess what keeps me going is the thought of my family staying together. I just want to help my son, support my wife, and be there for my daughter too. I don’t want to lose what we have, even though it feels like we’re on the edge right now. It’s all I want—to fix things and have us be okay again.

Your love and dedication to your family really shine through in what you’ve shared. Despite feeling at the edge, you’re holding tightly to the hope of bringing everyone back together and supporting them. That sounds like a powerful motivation. What do you think needs to happen for things to start feeling okay again, even in small ways?

Your love and dedication to your family are so clear in what you're saying. It’s clear how much you care about keeping everyone together and happy—it's not easy to carry all of that. If you were to imagine a small first step toward easing some of this stress, what do you think it would look like?
It sounded like you spoke very deeply about what your family means to you. How do you think that connects with the goals you laid out?

I think a small first step would be figuring out how to communicate better with my wife about everything. We’re both so tense, and it feels like we’re not on the same page when it comes to helping our son. If we could just work together without it turning into a fight, maybe we’d be able to make some progress.

Focusing on improving communication with your wife feels like a meaningful first step, especially since being on the same page might help you both approach things with your son together, rather than feeling divided. It sounds like you believe that teamwork between you and your wife could make a difference. What would working through conversations with her look like in a way that feels supportive for you both?

Focusing on communicating better with your wife sounds like a really constructive first step. It might help you both feel more like a team again, which could also create a clearer path for helping your son. What do you think gets in the way of those conversations going smoothly right now?

It seems you've understood how focusing on communication could help your relationship with your wife and support the needs of your son. Would you like to explore some ideas about constructive communication during conflict or ask your permission to discuss potential practices at this time?

I think what gets in the way is that we’re both so stressed and emotional about everything. When we try to talk, it just turns into frustration and blame. It’s hard to have a calm conversation when tensions are already so high.

It sounds like the stress and emotions create a cycle where it’s hard to communicate calmly and constructively, even though both of you likely want the same thing—for your family to be okay. Those high tensions must make it tough to feel connected during conversations. Would you like to explore ways to break that cycle, or is there something else about this you'd prefer to discuss?

It sounds like all the stress and emotion make it hard to have the kind of calm and productive conversations you want to have with your wife. It’s understandable that the frustration can get in the way when you both care so much about your family’s well-being. Do you think there’s a way to approach those talks differently, maybe at a time when things are a little less tense?
How do you feel about the idea of finding a calmer moment to start those conversations? Would that approach feel manageable for you and your wife?

Yeah, I think it might help, but it’s hard to find a time when things aren’t already tense. It’s like we’re always either tired, worried about our son, or just on edge. I guess we’d have to figure out how to take a step back first before even trying to talk.

It sounds like taking a step back feels like the key first move—especially since the constant stress seems to make it hard to find calm moments naturally. Even though things feel tense most of the time, wanting to find space to reconnect with your wife and talk more constructively shows a lot of intention and care on your part. What would taking that step back look like for you both?
